author: By The Editorial Board
title: Asian-Americans Are Scared for a Reason
description: Bigotry and demagoguing have pushed communities to a “crisis point.”
content: The grim reality of modern American life is that each new mass killing leads to a fevered study of motives and meaning. Was the latest shooter motivated by racism, misogyny, religion, revenge or some combination thereof? Those are not questions that members of a healthy society should routinely be forced to ask or answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Savoring the Office Bracket Pool in a Work-From-Home World
description: With far fewer gatherings available to compare notes and watch games, fans are connecting online to share the joy (and misery) of N.C.A.A. tournament pools.
content: It’s not just the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments that are back. So is the joy — and the heartache — of winning or bombing in a bracket pool every March, a shared experience taking on new appreciation in an era of coronavirus lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: A Stew That Captures the Essence of the Sea
description: A vibrant seafood stew, moqueca invigorates holiday menus and everyday meals alike.
content: Daniela Narcisco, a Brazilian cookbook author and food historian based in Florianópolis, the capital of Santa Catarina, Brazil, describes moqueca as “a wonderful addition to any Easter celebration.” And this seafood stew, built on a few simple yet deeply flavorful ingredients, is pleasing: Its vibrant broth is luscious and light, and evokes the essence of the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: To Save the Earth, Fall in Love
description: More people than ever visited national parks during the pandemic. We need to harness that interest for change.
content: Over the pandemic year, people took to appreciating the renewable delights of this ragged and tortured planet like never before. In this country, many national parks saw record crowds in 2020, and eight million more Americans went hiking than in the year before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Tales of Racism and Sexism, From 3 Leading Asian-American Women
description: Tina Tchen, Min Jin Lee, and Sung Yeon Choimorrow discuss the ‘unique way that Asian-American women experience sexual harassment.’
content: — Min Jin Lee, author of “Pachinko”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: How a Sham Candidate Helped Flip a Florida Election
description: The candidate and the man who prosecutors say recruited him to play spoiler in a Florida Senate race last year were both arrested this week.
content: MIAMI — The recruitment of the sham candidate began with a Facebook message at around 4 a.m. on May 15, 2020. “Call me,” a Florida legislator turned lobbyist wrote to an old friend. “I have a question for you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: For Rohingya Survivors, Art Bears Witness
description: They escaped traumatic circumstances in Myanmar and now live in harsh conditions. But refugees are creating murals drawn from their flourishing cultural traditions, reborn in Bangladesh camps.
content: Before he fled Myanmar in 2017, a witness to unspeakable horrors in his Rohingya village, Mohammed Nur would produce art in hiding, drawing on napkins and trash with bits of charcoal. Art, poetry readings and a university education were among many aspects of life that were not allowed for Rohingya Muslims like himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: There Was Nothing Trivial About Their First Date
description: An early sign that Adam Eversole and Kyle Fulton were compatible came when they attended a pub trivia night. They discovered they had complementary strengths.
content: When Dr. Gregory Kyle Fulton moved to New Orleans at the beginning of June 2013, he had “a new job, a new city, a new role in life,” he said — a clean slate. Soon, he also had a new partner in Adam Jacob Eversole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Oscar Lopez
title: 13 Law Enforcement Officers Killed in Mexico Ambush
description: The attack appeared to be the deadliest assault on the Mexican police in well over a year, illustrating the severe security challenges facing the government.
content: MEXICO CITY — Gunmen on Thursday ambushed a Mexican government convoy conducting a security patrol southwest of the capital, killing 13 prosecutors and police officers in what appeared to be the deadliest assault on Mexican law enforcement in well over a year, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Can the Makers of ‘Money Heist’ Mint Another Hit With ‘Sky Rojo’?
description: Álex Pina is back with another glitzy, over-the-top Spanish thriller for Netflix. This time, he and his creative partner say, the story is even leaner and the excess is even more over-the-top.
content: The new Spanish-language action series “Sky Rojo” is sheer excess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Nicole Hong and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: F.B.I. Investigating Whether Cuomo Aides Gave False Data on Nursing Homes
description: The inquiry has added to the legal pressure faced by Gov. Andrew Cuomo and his aides over the deaths of nursing home residents from Covid-19.
content: A federal investigation into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s handling of nursing homes during the pandemic has focused in recent weeks on whether the governor and his senior aides provided false data on resident deaths to the Justice Department, according to four people with knowledge of the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Zachary Small
title: Selling Art to Pay the Bills Divides the Nation’s Museum Directors
description: Bitter debate has ensued as museum leaders around the country discuss whether to permanently embrace a pandemic-spurred policy that allows the sale of art to cover some operating costs.
content: It started as a stopgap measure to respond to the pandemic, a temporary two-year loosening of an Association of Art Museum Directors’ policy that has long prohibited American institutions from selling art from their collections to help pay the bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: ‘Serial Stowaway’ Is Arrested at O’Hare (Again), 2 Days After TV Confessional
description: Marilyn Hartman, a 69-year-old woman notorious for sneaking aboard flights, was arrested on Tuesday in Chicago. Her lawyer suggested that she was set off by a recent TV news report about her.
content: A woman notorious for evading airport security and sneaking aboard planes without a ticket was arrested this week in Chicago, days after she was heard in a splashy TV news report promising that such escapades were behind her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Fear and Hostility Simmer as Ethiopia’s Military Keeps Hold on Tigray
description: Accounts of atrocities keep coming in as the wounded flee to the regional capital, Mekelle, where Tigrayans say they are being winnowed for their leaders’ rebellion.
content: The calm is deceptive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Whet Moser
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: More states said they will open vaccine appointments for the public in March or April.
content: States are racing to expand vaccine eligibility to all adults as part of a sprint to meet President Biden’s goal of universal vaccine access by May 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Mass shootings in public spaces had become less frequent during the pandemic.
description: Until Tuesday, when eight people were killed in Atlanta-area spas, it had been a year since there had been a large-scale shooting in a public place.
content: Until Tuesday, when eight people were killed in Atlanta-area spas, it had been a year since there had been a large-scale shooting in a public place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes and Alexis Soloski
title: Go or No? An Indoor Theater Invitation (at Last!) Needs an R.S.V.P.
description: Two critics, hungry for live performance, weigh whether they’re ready to take a health risk for “Blindness,” which opens in New York next month.
content: On Monday afternoon, theater critics in and around New York City received something they hadn’t seen in more than a year: an invitation to an in-person, indoor performance at an Off Broadway house. “Blindness,” Simon Stephens’s adaptation of the novel by José Saramago, directed by Walter Meierjohann and prerecorded by Juliet Stevenson, would open at the Daryl Roth Theater on April 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Ellis
title: My bracket has a final score tiebreaker. What should I write in?
description: Here’s a look at the average scores and average combined scores of recent college basketball national championship games.
content: After you’ve chosen the winners of 63 games — scientifically, of course — most bracket contests put one last obstacle between you and your expected winnings: a tiebreaker question that asks you to predict the final score of the championship game.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here are today’s scheduled games and how to stream them live.
description: Looking for a livestream for March Madness? Here’s where to find it.
content: As in recent years, the men’s games will be broadcast on CBS, TBS, TNT and TruTV. The official way to stream the tournament is through the N.C.A.A.’s March Madness Live app, which requires logging in through a TV provider. (The Paramount+ app, formerly known as CBS All Access, will also carry games broadcast on CBS.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: It Was an All-Star Weekend for the Bride and Groom
description: Basketball brought Christiana Barkley and Ilya Hoffman together in the first place, but he was far more impressed with her than he was with “the guy from ‘Space Jam.’”
content: Though Ilya Hoffman met Christiana Barkley during a basketball game, he wasn’t knocked sideways when he learned the identity of her father.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Daily: When Climate Change Comes to Your Yard
description: Interviewing a climate change skeptic who brought wind power to his community. Plus, a dispatch from a live concert and a new season of Still Processing.
content: Hi everyone, happy Friday. Last week, we asked you to tell us your favorite episode from the week, and our team Slack channel was soon filled with screenshots of your kind messages. So thank you, we appreciate you listening and sharing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: It’s My Idea. She’s Taking Credit.
description: What to do about copycats on Zoom calls, a rival’s resentment and managing an intern.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Ben Shpigel
title: Lawyer for Deshaun Watson’s Accusers Addresses Skeptics
description: “This case is about female empowerment, taking the power back,” said Tony Buzbee, who represents seven women in lawsuits accusing the Texans quarterback of sexual assault.
content: Tony Buzbee, the lawyer representing the seven women who have accused the Houston Texans star quarterback Deshaun Watson of sexual assault in civil lawsuits, on Friday spoke publicly for the first time since the allegations emerged this week. Buzbee forcefully challenged skepticism about the claims of assault, which he said had been echoed by as many as 15 other women, and about the timing of the lawsuits filed so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: From Love at First Sight to Becoming a Family of Eight
description: When Amber Morino’s friend tried to set her up with Peter Saji, she wasn’t interested in dating a TV writer. But their story changed rapidly after their first meeting.
content: Amber Morino, 34, almost missed out on meeting her now-husband after a friend recommended setting up the two. Upon finding out she was being hooked up with a TV writer and a creator of “Mixed-ish,” Ms. Morino turned down the gesture, prematurely deciding Peter Saji, 42, wouldn’t be her type.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ruth Graham and Jack Healy
title: Accused Gunman Had Visited Massage Parlors He Targeted, Police Say
description: The suspect, who was a customer at two of the spas in the Atlanta area that were attacked this week, spent time in a rehab clinic for a self-described sexual addiction.
content: ATLANTA — He checked himself into a rehab clinic for a self-described sexual addiction. He was so intent on avoiding pornography that he blocked websites from his computer and only used a flip phone. He worried to a roommate about falling “out of God’s grace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Azi Paybarah
title: Police Investigate Sexual Assault Allegation Against Armie Hammer
description: The Los Angeles Police Department disclosed the investigation after a woman said at a news conference that Mr. Hammer had sexually assaulted her in 2017.
content: The Los Angeles Police Department said on Thursday that it had opened an investigation into a woman’s allegation that she had been sexually assaulted by the actor Armie Hammer, whose Hollywood career has recently been derailed by allegations that he physically abused women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: What to Watch in the First Weekend of the Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Gonzaga will start its quest for six more wins and an undefeated season, and four teams are dealing with virus issues.
content: [See our complete guide to March Madness.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: How Nicknames for the Pandemic Became a Popular Online Trend
description: People have a range of nicknames for the pandemic: a panorama, a pandemonium, a “pandemi moore,” a panini. Is humor a useful way to cope with incredibly difficult times?
content: You probably didn’t realize how many words begin with the prefix “pan-” until we found ourselves living through a pan … demic. On social media, we are in a “panorama,” a “pandemonium,” a “pandemi moore,” a “panini.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gracy Olmstead
title: My Great-Grandfather Knew How to Fix America’s Food System
description: In the mutual aid and stewardship of an earlier generation of American farmers, there might be hope for our own communities.
content: The pandemic revealed just how brittle our food system has become. It has also made me think a lot about my paternal great-grandfather, Walter Howard, a farmer whom I knew as Grandpa Dad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emilie Poplett
title: The Dress Promised Me Something the Doctors Couldn’t
description: My obsessive online shopping wasn’t really about the clothes.
content: The dress was black with shiny buttons at the wrists and an oversized bow in the back. I said to my friend, “I want you to bury me in this dress,” which I found funny because I thought I was dying. And then I thought it wasn’t funny at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: White House Easter Egg Roll is canceled again because of the pandemic.
description: Instead, the White House Historical Association has released a virtual egg hunt.
content: Add the White House Easter Egg Roll to the list of yearly traditions canceled — once again — by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: The D.I.Y. Developers
description: After a young couple sold the Catskills retreat they built themselves for a nice profit, they started thinking bigger.
content: On a cold morning not long ago, Preston Jones and Ariana Diaz parked their car along a country road and hiked up into the land they bought last summer in Cornwallville, N.Y., in the northern Catskills. They built a campfire on a high meadow overlooking rolling farmland and mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: With ‘Zodiac,’ Mary Lou Williams Spanned Classical and Jazz
description: Two new interpretations show there are many ways to interpret a genre-crossing suite.
content: It’s only March, but the “Zodiac Suite,” written in 1945 by the composer and jazz pianist Mary Lou Williams, is already enjoying a momentous 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linsey Marr, Juliet Morrison and Caitlin Rivers
title: I Got My Covid Vaccine. Now Can I Hug My Mom?
description: Three experts respond to questions from readers about what they can do after getting vaccinated.
content: People want to know what they can do after they are vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: The Mobley Brothers Turned Backyard Brawls Into Basketball Stardom
description: Evan and Isaiah Mobley used to face off. Now they’re teammates at U.S.C., and Isaiah may be Evan’s biggest fan: “They haven’t really seen some of the abilities that he can really do.”
content: The backyard one-on-one basketball games between the brothers Isaiah and Evan Mobley came to a screeching halt early in their high school days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Amelia Nierenberg and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Andrew Cuomo, Tigray, March Madness: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Much Work is Too Much Work?
description: Junior bankers at Goldman Sachs raise pointed questions about pay, hours and working conditions.
content: A group of 13 disgruntled first-year analysts at Goldman Sachs made waves this week by assembling a professional-looking presentation in the company style about their experiences at the investment bank. The resulting “Working Conditions Survey” (sample size: 13) said that the junior bankers worked an average of around 100 hours per week, with most saying that they considered themselves victims of workplace abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: It’s OK to Feel Joy Right Now
description: Here’s how to prolong it.
content: The birds are chirping, a warm breeze is blowing and some of your friends are getting vaccinated. After a year of anxiety and stress, many of us are rediscovering what optimism feels like. And the good news about an increase in available vaccines could not come at a more joyous time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Falcon and the Winter Soldier’ Recap: Lost in America
description: The often thrilling first episode of this Disney+ series is likely to satisfy Marvel fans who’ve invested years in keeping track of these characters and their many, many problems.
content: Although the title of the latest Marvel Comics television series is “The Falcon and the Winter Solder,” the show is defined by another superhero entirely: the absent Captain America. Both the high-flying military operative Sam Wilson (Anthony Mackie) and the brainwashed, ageless assassin Bucky Barnes (Sebastian Stan) spent time as sidekicks to the original Captain, Steve Rogers, who at the end of the 2019 Marvel movie “Avengers: Endgame” retired from the hero business, leaving his old friends without a partner — or a mission. The question haunting Sam and Bucky now is, “What’s next?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grant Snider
title: What Would Make Someone the Worst Reader?
description: Do you watch the movie first? Have opinions on books you’ve never read? Flip to the last page? This might be you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Do You Think Are the Secrets to Happiness?
description: In a popular course at Yale University, students learn that the keys to happiness are sleep, gratitude and helping other people. Do you agree?
content: What do you think are the keys to happiness? Friendship and family? Love and laughter? Wisdom? Wealth? Or something else?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: She Awoke in Central Park, Handcuffed to a Stranger. What Happened?
description: That’s the premise of “Central Park,” by the French suspense king Guillaume Musso — just one of the novels in this week’s Crime column.
content: There’s some heavy irony at work in RED WIDOW (Putnam, 352 pp., $27) as one of its leads, the C.I.A. agent Lyndsey Duncan, is known by colleagues as the “human lie detector.” Polygraphs are so inaccurate that many courts won’t admit them as evidence. But their continued use by intelligence divisions is a metaphor for the lack of trust inherent in this work, a metaphor Alma Katsu employs in sly fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: A DeVos System Allowed 12 Minutes to Decide Student Loan Forgiveness
description: Education Dept. documents filed in federal court describe a process that denied 130,000 claims from borrowers who say schools misled them.
content: Former Education Secretary Betsy DeVos made no secret of her disdain for a program intended to forgive the federal student loans of borrowers who were ripped off by schools that defrauded their students. She called it a “free money” giveaway, let hundreds of thousands of claims languish for years and slashed the amount of relief granted to some successful applicants to $0.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Greg Steltenpohl, Pioneer in Plant-Based Drinks, Dies at 66
description: His first company, Odwalla, was crippled by a bacterial outbreak; he then started Califia Farms, now a leader in the beverage industry.
content: In 1980, Greg Steltenpohl and his hippie friends in Santa Cruz, Calif., bought a juicer for $250, began squeezing fresh orange juice and sold it out of the back of a Volkswagen van to support their real passion: playing jazz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In Russia, a Virus Lockdown Targets the Opposition
description: A court has confined 10 prominent opposition politicians and dissidents to house arrest, ostensibly for violating coronavirus safety rules.
content: MOSCOW — A Russian court has confined some of the country’s most prominent opposition figures to house arrest on accusations that they violated coronavirus safety rules, in what appears to be a government effort to use the restrictions to muzzle its opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy
title: The suspect wanted to curb his sexual urges, a former roommate says.
description: Months before Robert Aaron Long was charged with carrying out a bloody rampage at three massage parlors that horrified the nation and stoked a furious outcry over anti-Asian violence, the 21-year-old suspect who had grown up in a conservative Baptist church appeared fixated on guilt and lust.
content: Months before Robert Aaron Long was charged with carrying out a bloody rampage at three massage parlors that horrified the nation and stoked a furious outcry over anti-Asian violence, the 21-year-old suspect who had grown up in a conservative Baptist church appeared fixated on guilt and lust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden is ‘doing 100 percent fine’ after tripping while boarding Air Force One.
description: The president was on his way to Atlanta when he stumbled about midway up the stairs to board the plane.
content: President Biden was “doing fine” after falling off balance while boarding Air Force One before his Friday trip to Atlanta, according to a press secretary traveling with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlin Menza
title: Barefoot Dreams and the Conquest of Cozy
description: How one $180 microfiber blanket and its spinoffs came to to swaddle a nation.
content: The first time Amanda John glimpsed a Barefoot Dreams blanket, she was watching “Keeping Up With the Kardashians.” “Khloé was wearing her little leopard blanket and I was like, ‘What is that?’ Then, when I Googled it, I had a little bit of sticker shock,” said Ms. John, 32, who lives in Atlanta and whose blog, Strawberry Chic, focuses on “sharing style for the everyday girly girl.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Looking at the Rise of Anti-Asian Racism in the Pandemic
description: Friday: One expert discusses how anti-Asian sentiment tends to rise in times of national crisis. Also: Pandemic updates.
content: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Lipsky
title: How the Illegal Rave Scene Thrives During the Pandemic
description: Nightclubs are still officially closed in New York, but underground parties are there if you know where to look.
content: On New Year’s Eve, Sam Adeelmirza, the event organizer known as Sam Black, still felt cagey about attending a dance party; he did not want a repeat of the rave he organized under the Kosciuszko Bridge in August. That party was supposed to have been a guerrilla fund-raiser for Legal Aid, but it quickly got out of hand. Hundreds came, and after the second time the police showed up, the event was shut down. Footage of the rave spread to social media, and the beating he took in the press still stung.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Insiders Jockey for Whittled-Down Ambassadorship Slots
description: Hundreds of donors and former lawmakers, who have not been Foreign Service officers but are close to the president, are said to be clamoring for about 35 ambassadorship slots available.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has begun reviewing a list of finalists to serve as key ambassadors as he seeks to cut down on the number of political appointees his predecessor Donald J. Trump installed at embassies abroad, and to send a signal to career Foreign Service officials that they are valued once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Looking Out
description: What do you think this image is saying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Obama’s picks: Gonzaga in the men’s tournament, Baylor in the women’s.
description: Former President Barack Obama is forecasting some first-round upsets but only limited chaos late in the men’s and women’s tournaments.
content: Former President Barack Obama is forecasting some first-round upsets but only limited chaos late in the men’s and women’s tournaments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Hannah
title: Why Is It So Tough to Leave Afghanistan?
description: The foreign policy establishment just can’t admit when it got things wrong.
content: As his two predecessors did, President Biden has pledged to end the war in Afghanistan. But also as his two predecessors did, he could end up tragically perpetuating it. Outnumbered by a national security establishment fixated on continuing this misadventure, the Biden team will need courage and clarity if it is to finally disentangle America from what has become a futile struggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Jack Healy and Frances Robles
title: Suspect’s Church Calls Spa Attacks ‘the Result of a Sinful Heart’
description: The church said the killing of eight people at Atlanta spas was “an extreme and wicked act.” Police records show prostitution-related arrests at one of the targeted businesses between 2011 and 2014.
content: The Southern Baptist church that counted the suspect in a series of deadly spa shootings as an active member said on Friday that the attacks were “the result of a sinful heart and depraved mind” and that it had begun the process of removing him from its membership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Home, but Never Alone
description: Privacy is close to nonexistent for those lucky enough to be holed up with loved ones during the pandemic. So, where do you go when you need to complain about those dear and very near?
content: Of everything the pandemic has stripped from her, Juliana Jackson, 31, a second-grade teacher in Denver, misses her alone time the most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Summers We Won’t See Again
description: The 2019 signings of Eden Hazard (by Real Madrid) and Antoine Griezmann (by Barcelona) already feel like they’re from another era. It’s one that might be gone for good.
content: All was right with the world. There were 50,000 or so Real Madrid fans packed into the Santiago Bernabéu, all there to catch a glimpse of the latest gift bestowed upon them by Florentino Pérez, their club’s president. Out on the field, Eden Hazard was juggling a ball from one foot to another as the cameras flashed and the crowd cooed its approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France resumes use of AstraZeneca’s vaccine for those over 55, and the prime minister gets the shot.
description: France resumed administering the AstraZeneca vaccine on Friday, but only to people aged 55 and above, as the country’s prime minister himself got a shot live on television to restore crucial trust in the jab.
content: France resumed administering the AstraZeneca vaccine on Friday, but only to people aged 55 and above, as the country’s prime minister himself got a shot live on television to restore crucial trust in the jab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Lets Break for Banks Expire but Opens Door to Future Changes
description: The central bank had exempted safe assets from a crucial regulatory requirement, in a bid to keep markets chugging last year.
content: The Federal Reserve said on Friday that it would not extend a temporary exemption of a rule that dictates the amount of capital banks must keep in reserve, a loss for big banks and their lobbyists, who had been pushing to extend the relief beyond its March 31 expiration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Reed Disputes Groping Allegation, Calling Woman’s Account ‘Not Accurate’
description: The congressman from New York, who has been eyeing a run against Gov. Andrew Cuomo, did not specify what parts of the account of his actions in a bar in 2017 were inaccurate.
content: Representative Tom Reed, Republican of New York, on Friday disputed the accuracy of a news report detailing the allegations of a former lobbyist who said he touched her inappropriately during a weekend political trip in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Another Big Step Toward Digitizing Our Lives
description: On Beeple, Nyan Cat and the latest tech phenom: the non-fungible token, or NFT.
content: For those scratching their heads about the latest tech phenom called non-fungible tokens, or NFTs, I have one simple sentence to explain it all: Everything that can be digitized will be digitized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Make the Persian chicken stew known as khoresh-e fesenjoon, coconut macaroons with chocolate, or a cheesy baked polenta with tomato sauce.
content: Good morning. Nowruz, the Persian New Year, is tomorrow, and, if the feasting and exchanging of presents will be muted this year because of the pandemic, we’ve still got loads of recipes appropriate to the holiday. Take a look at Samin Nosrat’s khoresh-e fesenjoon, for instance, a Persian chicken stew with pomegranate molasses and walnuts (above). You could serve that with sabzi polo, herbed rice with tahdig, and salad-e shirazi, a salad of cucumber, tomatoes and onion. That would be a very nice meal. (And it would yield tremendous leftovers, too.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Johnson
title: Mr. Biden, Enough With the Tough Talk on China
description: Modest measures can reverse the dangerous decay in relations.
content: Since taking office nearly two months ago, the Biden administration has been a whirlwind of activity in reforming and revisiting almost every key problem area but one: the chaotic and incoherent China policy it inherited from the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: ‘This Is Jim Crow in New Clothes’
description: Senator Raphael Warnock’s first speech on the Senate floor brought the past into the present.
content: Senator Raphael Warnock gave his first speech on the Senate floor on Wednesday. The subject? Voting rights.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Rebecca Traister
description: The March 19 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Rebecca Traister. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: In First Talks, Dueling Accusations Set Testy Tone for U.S.-China Diplomacy
description: U.S. officials said the two days of discussions would continue, but accused the Chinese delegation of violating the format for meetings that had sought to find common ground between the superpowers.
content: ANCHORAGE — Even before the Biden administration’s first face-to-face meeting with senior Chinese diplomats on Thursday, American officials predicted the discussions would not go well. They were right: The traditional few minutes of opening greetings and remarks dissolved into more than an hour of very public verbal jousting, confirming the expected confrontational tone between the geopolitical rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: With Disruption and Trolling, Greene Reflects G.O.P.’s Shift
description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene said being booted from committees left more time for her to push her party to the right. She’s part of a new wave of lawmakers more interested in brand-building than lawmaking.
content: WASHINGTON — When Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene was expelled from her congressional committees as punishment for conspiracy mongering and violent statements, she embraced her exile, declaring that she had been “freed” from the obligation to participate in the drudgery of legislating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Live-event businesses will be able to apply for a relief grant program starting April 8.
description: Applicants are eligible for grants of up to $10 million from the Shuttered Venue Operators Grant fund, which Congress created in the economic relief bill passed in December.
content: A $16 billion federal relief fund for live-event businesses like music clubs, theaters, museums and concert promoters will start taking applications on April 8, according to the Small Business Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Growing Power of Asian-Americans in Georgia Now Comes With Fear’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the recent shootings in Atlanta, the history of anti-Asian racism and how the violence has affected Asian-Americans in Georgia.
content: Note to Teachers: This lesson deals with anti-Asian violence and racism. To prepare yourself and your students, you might first read “Addressing Anti-Asian Racism With Students” from the Smithsonian Asian Pacific American Center or “Responding to Anti-Asian Violence and Georgia Shootings” from Learning for Justice. Depending on your identity, and the identity of your students, this guide “Self-Care Tips For Asian-Americans Dealing With Racism Amid Coronavirus” from HuffPost might be helpful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Celebrate the Spring Holidays Safely With Your Family
description: Easter, Passover and Ramadan will be a little less lonely this year as more people get vaccinated. But experts say we can’t let down our guard just yet.
content: The weather is warming, the days are looking brighter and the number of people getting vaccinated is on the rise. So can we finally celebrate the spring holidays together like we used to, back when we could see the bottom halves of everyone’s faces?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: In Restricting Early Voting, the Right Sees a New ‘Center of Gravity’
description: Donald Trump is no longer center stage. But many conservative activists are finding that the best way to raise money and keep voters engaged is to make his biggest fabrication their top priority.
content: For more than a decade, the Susan B. Anthony List and the American Principles Project have pursued cultural and policy priorities from the social conservative playbook, one backing laws to ban abortion once a fetal heartbeat could be detected and the other opposing civil rights protections for L.G.B.T.Q. people. From their shared offices in suburban Virginia, they and their affiliated committees spent more than $20 million on elections last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: grimace
description: This word has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Sam’s Club C.E.O. on the Company’s High Sales and Low Wages
description: Kathryn McLay, an Australian who worked for years in finance, wants employees to know “how valued they are.”
content: As proposals to raise the federal minimum wage gain more bipartisan support, all eyes are on Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer. When Walmart acts, other companies follow. And for now at least, Walmart continues to resist calls to raise its minimum starting wage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: U.S. Rushes to Expand Covid Vaccine Eligibility in a ‘Race Against Time’
description: As coronavirus cases nationwide have plateaued, at least 20 states have committed in recent days to widening the list of people who may get a vaccine.
content: CHICAGO — Officials in at least 20 states have committed in recent days to opening coronavirus vaccine appointments to all adults in March or April, part of a fast-moving expansion as states race to meet President Biden’s goal of universal eligibility by May 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: The Making of an Especially Intricate Fendi Baguette Bag
description: A new limited edition of the iconic style was hand-embroidered with a centuries-old technique.
content: In 1997, the Fendi Baguette debuted in a rainbow of shades, kicking off the hedonistic It bag era, a time that was as carefree as it now seems distant. Just like the golden bread it’s named for, which the French are known to carry under their arms, the petite shoulder bag has never gone out of style. But now its architect, Silvia Venturini Fendi, the brand’s 60-year-old artistic director of accessories and men’s wear, is reimagining the Baguette as a vehicle through which to explore her country’s enduring relationship to craft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Kyiv enters a three-week lockdown.
description: Ukraine’s capital will become the latest European city to go into lockdown, with strict three-week measures being introduced for Kyiv on Saturday as vaccinations failed to prevent a third wave of coronavirus infections.
content: Ukraine’s capital will become the latest European city to go into lockdown, with strict three-week measures being introduced for Kyiv on Saturday as vaccinations failed to prevent a third wave of coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Andrew Cuomo and the Performance of Power
description: Rebecca Traister and Ezra Klein discuss the New York governor’s fall from grace, toxic workplaces and the aesthetic of strongmen leaders.
content: Six months ago, Andrew Cuomo was on top of the world. He was touted as the anti-Donald Trump — the calm, fact-driven coronavirus leader the country needed. Now, amid allegations of hiding the true number of Covid-19 deaths in New York nursing homes and of workplace sexual harassment and abusive behavior, most of the state’s major Democratic politicians are calling for Cuomo’s resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: A Designer Who Finds Beauty in Austerity
description: For Loren Daye, stripping a space back to its most essential elements is an aesthetic practice to live by.
content: FROM THE BEGINNING, the interior designer Loren Daye appreciated the invisible. “I love anonymity and seeing without being seen,” she says. “The door you don’t notice until it’s open, the building you never realized was there, the quiet person at the party.” Growing up in Bowling Green, Ohio, she often hung out in her parents’ closets. After her father, a professor of Buddhist philosophy, was hired by the University of East Anglia, the family moved to its concrete campus in Norwich, England, where, in the attic of their new home, Daye transformed a giant cupboard into a reading room. From there, she taught herself about Denys Lasdun, the Brutalist English architect who in the 1960s designed the iconic, tiered postwar structures that surrounded their apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Why Child Care Staff Had to Show Up While Teachers Worked Remotely
description: The pandemic has spotlighted disparities in working conditions between child care workers and teachers.
content: Last summer, when New York City abruptly delayed the start of in-person classes, the Cypress Hills Child Care Corporation in Brooklyn opened right on schedule — complete with a spray of balloons tied to the front door and festive music booming from a speaker. And when the entire public school system shut down in November because of rising virus cases, the state required the center and many other child care facilities across the city to stay open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Unexpected Dinner Inspiration
description: Make supremely fast salmon, or delight in the deliciousness of a fried breaded cutlet.
content: A year into this pandemic, I’m taking dinner ideas wherever they come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Yearning for Life on Tour, Roadies Open Up Online
description: Backstage music crews were set adrift by the pandemic. For some, a weekly Zoom group has been the answer.
content: LONDON — William Frostman, a lighting supervisor who has toured with the Rolling Stones and Queen, has just spent a whole year at home, the longest time in his decades-long career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heidi Shin
title: I’m Helping My Korean-American Daughter Embrace Her Identity to Counter Racism
description: “I’m not sure Asian-American families can avoid ‘the talk’ any longer,” one expert said.
content: My daughter was the only kid who didn’t have a separate Korean name when we signed her up for Korean classes three years ago. The blank space on the registration form looked at me, as if to say we’d forgotten something as parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss and Hilary Howard
title: How Essential Workers Who Shared Their Sundays With Us Are Doing, One Year In
description: A nurse struggles with low morale; a waiter worries about a rush to normalcy; a respiratory therapist recovers from Covid, and more.
content: Last March the Sunday Routine column, which typically profiles New Yorkers enjoying the city on their day off, switched gears to profile essential workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: ‘A long line of hate’ against Asian-Americans in N.Y.C.
description: The community is grappling with the reality that the law is not designed for the ways in which people of Asian descent experience racism.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: ‘The Market Seems Crazy’: Start-Ups Wrestle With Flood of Offers
description: As a deal frenzy mounts, propelled by financial vehicles known as SPACs, start-ups have become the prey.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Ryan Schaffer, chief financial officer of Expensify, a start-up that makes business expense reporting software, has been relentlessly hounded since last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Democrats Confront a Surge at the Border
description: The House is passing popular legislation, but an influx of migrants at the border presents another conundrum.
content: The Democratic-led House on Thursday passed bills that would offer a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, including so-called Dreamers, and eventually grant legal status to almost a million farmworkers and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: More Charming
description: Kameron Austin Collins appeals with a challenging Friday puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This grid is a few steps into Saturday territory, if you ask me, mainly because of a) the lack of real “gimme” clues to gain an entry point and b) the dollop of hard-to-deduce fill, in words like OMSK and NINON (there are more).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: White House employees resign after past marijuana use, despite the administration’s more permissive stance.
description: The episode highlights how murky the new guidelines are, particularly for a White House that has pledged to embrace progressive positions.
content: In February, the Biden administration signaled that past marijuana use would not necessarily disqualify a person from employment in the federal government. It was a change that was seen as a way to open the door for younger talent, but one that only took a few weeks to be tested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Myanmar Protesters Answer Military’s Bullets With an Economic Shutdown
description: From hospitals, railways and dockyards to schools, shops and trading houses, the country is at a standstill. Strikers hope their actions will force the army to return power after its coup on Feb. 1.
content: Bank tellers’ windows are gathering dust. Cargo at the port sits uncollected. And in grand government ministries in Naypyidaw, the capital of Myanmar, stacks of documents are curling in the humidity. There are few people to process all the paperwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Minor Feelings’ and ‘Bubblegum’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE ILLNESS LESSON, by Clare Beams. (Anchor, 288 pp., $16.) It’s 1871 in small-town Massachusetts. Eight female students at odds with the male founder of a girls school fall mysteriously ill, but are told they are not ill. “Then there is that flock of ‘disastrous-bright’ red birds that shows up, inexplicably, one day, injecting an element of Hitchcockian surrealism” into this “sly,” “astoundingly original” debut novel that, according to our reviewer, Siobhan Jones, “belongs on the shelf with your Margaret Atwood and Octavia Butler collections.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: The Pay TV Model Is Declining. The N.F.L. Is Still Banking on It.
description: In their agreements with the league, networks promoted their digital rights. But the structure of the deals allows consumers to watch most games without subscribing to a streaming service.
content: The biggest conglomerates in television collectively agreed to spend more than $100 billion to continue putting N.F.L. games on their broadcast and cable television channels for the next decade, but the way they announced the deals on Thursday did not make that immediately apparent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: AstraZeneca vaccine ‘safe and effective.’
content: The European Medicines Agency said on Thursday that the AstraZeneca vaccine was safe and effective, a finding that could prompt more than a dozen countries, including Germany, France and Italy, to resume use after temporary suspensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: For the First Time, a North Korean Is Set to Be Extradited to the U.S.
description: Malaysia’s agreement to extradite the man is a victory in Washington’s efforts to crack down on what it has called sanctions-evading activities by North Koreans.
content: SEOUL — North Korea on Friday severed diplomatic ties with Malaysia after that country’s highest court agreed to extradite a North Korean man accused of money laundering to the United States, a major coup in Washington’s efforts to choke Pyongyang’s illicit trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The Water on Mars Vanished. This Might Be Where It Went.
description: Mars once had rivers, lakes and seas. Although the planet is now desert dry, scientists say most of the water is still there, just locked up in rocks.
content: Mars was once wet, with an ocean’s worth of water on its surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Edgar Sandoval, Anne Berryman and Corina Knoll
title: What We Know About the Victims in the Atlanta Shootings
description: Six of the eight people killed at Atlanta-area spas on Tuesday were women of Asian descent.
content: Eight people were killed at three massage businesses in Atlanta and nearby Cherokee County on Tuesday. The suspect in the shootings, Robert Aaron Long, has been charged with eight counts of murder and one count of aggravated assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Carl Reiner’s Archives Will Go to the National Comedy Center
description: The collection of papers, artifacts and memorabilia spans Reiner’s career and work on “Your Show of Shows,” “The Dick Van Dyke Show” and beyond.
content: When Carl Reiner died last June, he left a hole in the comedy firmament that no performer, writer or director will be able to fill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Top Woman in Canada’s Military Issues a Stinging Rebuke of Its Culture
description: In a letter, one of the Canadian military’s most prominent women resigned, saying she’s “sickened” by sexual misconduct allegations.
content: OTTAWA — For Lt. Col. Eleanor Taylor it was the last straw. The simultaneous investigations of the Canadian military’s top commander and his predecessor that were announced last month led her to write a stinging letter of resignation from the army reserve after more than 26 years of service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: TV’s Battle of the Binge: Why the Wait Can Be Worth It
description: Streaming TV promised to free us from schedules, but series like “WandaVision” show that weekly rituals still have power.
content: Disney+’s “WandaVision” began with a bold, disorienting move, taking viewers and depositing them without explanation into an unsettling bubble of 1950s television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: As Republicans Shun Vaccines, Congress Toils to Return to Normal
description: A quarter of lawmakers have yet to receive a coronavirus vaccine, even though they have been available since December.
content: WASHINGTON — Even as Americans across the country hunt for a lifesaving shot in a bid to get back to a semblance of prepandemic normalcy, more than a quarter of members of Congress, just a phone call away from receiving a coronavirus vaccine, have turned it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: ‘I Have Shut a Lot of People Up’
description: Long denied his dream of an N.B.A. coaching job, Patrick Ewing has gained respect by leading the Georgetown Hoyas back to the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament.
content: Patrick Ewing was upset last week when unwitting security staff at Madison Square Garden asked him for identification in the hallways of a building he called home for 15 years. They were unaware, apparently, that the former star of the Knicks, whose No. 33 hangs in tribute inside the famed arena, was the same man coaching the Georgetown men’s basketball team at the Big East Tournament there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris met with Asian-American leaders in Atlanta.
description: The president has ordered that American flags be flown at half-staff to honor the victims of the Atlanta spa shootings.
content: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, the first Asian-American in the role, met with Asian-American leaders in Atlanta on Friday afternoon after a shooting rampage at Asian massage businesses left eight people dead this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Meme Stocks, Bias in A.I. and Instagram Book Clubs: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: Take out your headphones, put down your phone and listen to New York Times journalism narrated by the reporters who wrote the story, or by world-class narrators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Biden Has Disappeared
description: His presidency will be transformational to the extent that he transforms himself.
content: For the life of me, I can’t find Joe Biden. Should we send a search party?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: ‘I’m in a really dark place’: Complaints at Goldman Sachs set off a workplace debate.
description: A group of analysts rated their job satisfaction as two out of 10 and said they were unlikely to stay at Goldman in six months if working conditions remained the same.
content: A group of 13 disgruntled first-year analysts at Goldman Sachs has made waves by assembling a professional-looking presentation in the company’s style about their experiences at the investment bank. The resulting “Working Conditions Survey” (polling the 13 analysts who created the slide deck) that circulated on social media this week said they worked an average of around 100 hours per week, with most saying they considered themselves victims of workplace abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: Sours That Walk the Line
description: The drink has countless variations, but a simple spirit-citrus-sweetener formula is at the heart of all of them.
content: The three-piece suit of the cocktail set, the sour formula is simple and timeless: spirit, citrus and sweetener. Sometimes, though not always, an egg white is added.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: At This N.C.A.A. Tournament, Orange Is the New Bracket
description: The color orange has developed a utilitarian reputation in the United States — except in college sports, where it makes a statement.
content: [See our complete guide to March Madness.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: When Gameday Is a Crime Scene
description: A string of robberies at the homes of soccer stars has cast a spotlight on the wealthy athlete’s newest luxury items: protection dogs, private guards and even panic rooms.
content: Ángel Di María got the news as soon as he stepped off the field. Pulling him in the middle of a tie game appeared to make little sense, but Paris St.-Germain’s coach quickly provided an explanation: Di María’s wife had called the team’s security officer. He needed to get home immediately. His family’s house had just been robbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: The Senate’s ‘Talking Filibuster’ Might Rise Again
description: President Biden and some Democrats support changing Senate rules to require holding the floor with speeches — and, perhaps, singing and recitations from Dr. Seuss. Here’s how that worked in the past.
content: If the filibuster did not exist, Senate Democrats could use the hair-thin majority they won in January to pursue an ambitious legislative agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Violent attacks against Asian-Americans persist in the Bay Area.
description: This week alone in San Francisco three Asian people were attacked on downtown streets.
content: In early February, Asian-American community leaders in the San Francisco Bay Area organized protests after the killing of an older Thai man and a spate of attacks in Oakland’s Chinatown. Prosecutors, politicians and police chiefs called the attacks intolerable and vowed to crack down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: A Home Away From the Virus, However You Can Find It
description: Whether hitting the road or sailing out to sea, restless families are packing up and ‘slow traveling’ to new destinations.
content: Last June, as Americans began to emerge from lockdowns and into a new, uncertain stage of the pandemic, Amy Ryan and her family set sail in a 44-foot-long catamaran and headed up the Atlantic coast. They haven’t stopped sailing since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Theater Actors Step Up Push for Union to Allow Them to Work
description: Nearly 2,000 performers have petitioned Actors’ Equity for guidelines that will speed up a return to the stage.
content: As states around the nation move toward reopening, theater actors and stage managers are protesting what they see as their union’s slow pace toward helping them get back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: Why Are We Worrying About Women’s Work?
description: Some liberals are wrongly concerned that the child benefit in the Biden rescue plan could help poor mothers stay home.
content: It seems politicians do sometimes keep their promises. President Biden campaigned on a pledge of newfound political consensus, and he has delivered on one point, at least, even if it is not one he might have expected: Commenters on the right and left are concerned that the child tax credit in the American Rescue Plan Act — up to $3,600 for children 5 and under, and up to $3,000 for kids 6 to 17 — will discourage women from working outside the home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: A Pro-Europe, Anti-Populist Youth Party Scored Surprising Gains in the Dutch Elections
description: For years, right-wing populists have been a driving force in the Netherlands. But this week a pan-European party called Volt shook things up.
content: Lost among the mostly humdrum national elections in the Netherlands this week was the emergence of Volt, an anti-populist, pro-Europe party made up of students and young professionals that snatched three seats in the Dutch Parliament — the first national electoral success in its five years of existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Britain’s ‘One-Jab’ Strategy
description: Britain’s “one-jab” strategy is working, offering lessons for the world.
content: The global leaders in Covid-19 vaccination rates are Israel and the United Arab Emirates. After them come a handful of countries that have each given between 30 and 45 shots for every 100 residents, including the United States, Britain, Bahrain, Chile and Serbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: No. 15 seed Oral Roberts upset No. 2 seed Ohio State in overtime.
description: Oral Roberts has joined an elite club.
content: Oral Roberts has joined an elite club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: ‘Stupid’ DoorDash Side Job Gets Pennsylvania Prosecutor Demoted
description: The district attorney for Bucks County, Pa., said Gregg Shore, a high-ranking prosecutor, had been making food deliveries during work hours for the county. “I don’t know why he did this,” he said.
content: Gregg Shore prosecuted high-profile cases in a suburb of Philadelphia, earning a six-figure salary and reaching the second-highest post in a district attorney’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: A Paris Opera Ballet Étoile on Being Young, Gifted and Successful
description: Hugo Marchand talks about his memoir, “Danser,” about the intensity of the company and about dancing with Anselm Kiefer paintings.
content: Hugo Marchand, probably the starriest of the Paris Opera Ballet’s stars, or étoiles, stares out, bare-chested and muscled, from the cover of his new memoir, “Danser” (Arthaud), published in France last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: The Strange History of Harmony Day and Australia’s Racism Discussion
description: For some, the best way to tackle racism is to not mention it and instead use “more encouraging words.”
content: Two weeks ago, four local councilors of Asian heritage across Sydney received letters calling for death to “all Chinese people.” On Wednesday night, one of them proposed a motion for his council to take part in a campaign called “Racism Not Welcome.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Not everyone stayed home during the pandemic. Some hit the road, while others took to the sea.
description: Last June, as Americans began to emerge from lockdowns and into a new yet still uncertain stage of the pandemic, Amy Ryan and her family set sail in a 44-foot catamaran and headed up the Atlantic coast. They haven’t stopped sailing since.
content: Last June, as Americans began to emerge from lockdowns and into a new yet still uncertain stage of the pandemic, Amy Ryan and her family set sail in a 44-foot catamaran and headed up the Atlantic coast. They haven’t stopped sailing since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Roger Baldwin, Groundbreaker in Blackjack Strategy, Dies at 91
description: He and three math-minded Army buddies — the “Four Horsemen of Aberdeen” — used calculators to figure out how to give players an edge against the casino.
content: Roger Baldwin was an Army private in 1953 playing blackjack in the barracks at the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland when another serviceman said something that piqued his curiosity: that dealers at casinos in Nevada were required to draw a card when their hands totaled 16 or less, but that they could stick with their hands at 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: The police made prostitution arrests at one of the spas in the attacks several years ago.
description: At least 11 people arrested at Gold Spa in northeast Atlanta were charged with prostitution-related offenses between 2011 and 2014.
content: The Atlanta Police Department arrested at least 11 people and charged them with prostitution-related offenses between 2011 and 2014 at a massage business where three women were killed this week, according to department records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dennis Mileti, Expert on Preparing for Disasters, Dies at 75
description: He was dismayed at the mixed messaging on Covid-19. The virus killed him.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: The Obstacles to Reporting on Black Representation in Fashion
description: Times journalists asked leading companies about the racial makeup of their work forces. The responses, or the lack of them, were revealing. Here, the reporters discuss what they found.
content: Leaders in the fashion world have pledged to address racism in their business. But to determine whether anything is improving, reporters for The New York Times felt they needed a concrete set of data about the current state of Black representation in the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Women Posing in Children’s Clothing? Fad Sparks Body-Shaming Concerns.
description: It’s the latest viral challenge to sweep Chinese social media, igniting worries that it reinforces the country’s narrow beauty norms.
content: The children’s clothing section at Uniqlo in China has gained an unexpected new clientele: adult women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: An 89-Year-Old Sharpshooter Takes Aim at India’s Patriarchy
description: Chandro Tomar’s husband and other male relatives tried to forbid her trips to a local shooting range. Now, she’s won dozens of medals and become a feminist icon in the country.
content: The 89-year-old woman stood in the courtyard of her home in northern India and picked up an air pistol. She tucked her pink head scarf securely into the waist of her long skirt and steadied her arm, looking through the sights at her target, a bottle about 12 feet away. She fired, and the bottle came tumbling down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I’m an Athlete, How Can I Find Clothes That Fit?
description: Vanessa Friedman, fashion director of The New York Times, takes reader questions.
content: The problem of fashion and fit is a perennial bugaboo. I remember interviewing Janice Wang of Alvanon, a business making fit mannequins for brands she started precisely because she discovered that the standard sizing was based on measurements taken in the middle of the last century in America, when bodies, obviously, were pretty different for a variety of reasons. (Her company actually scanned current bodies to create a new prototype.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Kingsbury
title: It’s Been a Long, Cold, Lonely Winter
description: Spring is here. So is the end of the pandemic. Almost.
content: It’s spring, when a young man’s fancy lightly turns to thoughts of life without a killer virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Biden Nominates Former Florida Senator to Lead NASA
description: Bill Nelson flew on a space shuttle in 1986 and lost re-election for a fourth Senate term in 2018. Some space advocates fear his approach to the agency could take it backward.
content: President Biden on Friday nominated Bill Nelson, a former senator from Florida, to head NASA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi

title: Europe’s Vaccine Ethics Call: Do No Harm and Let More Die?

title: How Close Are China and Germany? Consider ‘Little Swabia.’
description: The city of Taicang illustrates the tight ties between the countries — and how difficult it could be for President Biden to win allies in his campaign to isolate Beijing.
content: TAICANG, China — German and Chinese flags flutter along tree-lined avenues. Workers are erecting a shopping-and-hotel project with the half-timbered style of architecture more typically found in places like Bavaria or the Black Forest. A nearby restaurant serves Thuringia grilled sausages, fried pork sausages and lots of sauerkraut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: 30 Years After Anita Hill, We Should All Know What Sexual Harassment Is
description: Governor Cuomo championed the laws that made it easier to punish workplace harassment. Why is he unclear about them?
content: If you work alongside other human beings, you are probably familiar with sexual harassment video training. Presented as a quiz with multiple choice answers, it features actors performing various scenarios — around stacking shelves, in cubicles, at happy hour — that leave you to make the requisite judgment calls. “Hey, Sally,’’ Bob from receiving might say, “Let’s talk about a promotion for you. Over strip steak. At my place.” Typically, the correct responses do not demand a deep dive into case law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Five Who Used Marijuana in Past Will Exit White House, Calling New Guidelines Into Question
description: The episode highlighted how murky new guidelines toward past use are, particularly for a White House that has pledged to embrace progressive positions.
content: WASHINGTON — In February, the Biden administration signaled that past marijuana use would not necessarily disqualify a person from employment by relaxing longstanding policies that have barred some past users of the drug from working in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Why U.S. Cruises Are Still Stuck in Port
description: Six months ago, the C.D.C. lifted its “no sail” order for American cruise companies, but they haven’t started sailing — and likely won’t soon. An explainer.
content: In October, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lifted its “no sail” order on U.S. cruise ships and set out a framework that would allow them to start sailing again, bringing relief and hope to a decimated industry — and to many cruise fans.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Kenneth Cooper, a harpsichordist, pianist and musicologist who was acclaimed for performances of Baroque music that balanced historical insights with engaging spontaneity, whose nearly 100 recordings included forays into contemporary works and ragtime, and whose collaborators included Yo-Yo Ma, died on March 13 in Manhattan. He was 79.

content: To many Canadians, it seemed decidedly unneighborly. Canada’s initial coronavirus vaccination program moved at a stately pace over the winter, while inoculations in the United States raced ahead. But Washington was unwilling to share any of its stockpile of tens of millions of doses of a vaccine it had yet to approve for use by Americans.
